name: text
desc: Archival Location. Indicates where the subject of the file is archived.

name: text
desc: Genre. Describes the original work, such as "landscape", "portrait", "still life", etc.

name: text
desc: Keywords. Provides a list of keywords that refer to the file or subject of the file. Separate multiple keywords with a semicolon and a blank. For example, "Seattle; aerial view; scenery".

name: text
desc: Lightness. Describes the changes in lightness settings on the digitizer required to produce the file. Note that the format of this information depends on hardware used.

name: text
desc: Medium. Describes the original subject of the file, such as "computer image", "drawing", "lithograph", and so forth.

name: text
desc: Name. Stores the title of the subject of the file, such as "Seattle From Above".

name: text
desc: Palette Setting. Specifies the number of colors requested when digitizing an image, such as "256".

name: text
desc: Product. Specifies the name of the title the file was originally intended for, such as "Encyclopedia of Pacific Northwest Geography".

name: text
desc: Subject. Describes the contents of the file, such as "Aerial view of Seattle".

name: text
desc: Software. Identifies the name of the software package used to create the file, such as "Microsoft WaveEdit".

name: text
desc: Sharpness. Identifies the changes in sharpness for the digitizer required to produce the file (the format depends on the hardware used).

name: text
desc: Artist. Lists the artist of the original subject of the file. For example, "Michaelangelo".

name: text
desc: Source. Identifies the name of the person or organization who supplied the original subject of the file. For example, "Trey Research".

name: text
desc: Source Form. Identifies the original form of the material that was digitized, such as "slide", "paper", "map", and so forth. This is not necessarily the same as IMED.

name: text
desc: Technician. Identifies the technician who digitized the subject file. For example, "Smith, John."

name: text
desc: Commissioned. Lists the name of the person or organization that commissioned the subject of the file. For example, "Pope Julian II".

name: text
desc: Comments. Provides general comments about the file or the subject of the file. If the comment is several sentences long, end each sentence with a period. Do not include newline characters.

name: text
desc: Copyright. Records the copyright information for the file. For example, "Copyright Encyclopedia International 1991." If there are multiple copyrights, separate them by a semicolon followed by a space.

name: text
desc: Creation date. Specifies the date the subject of the file was created. List dates in year-month-day format, padding one-digit months and days with a zero on the left. For example, "1553-05-03" for May 3, 1553.

name: text
desc: Cropped. Describes whether an image has been cropped and, if so, how it was cropped. For example, "lower right corner". IDIM Dimensions. Specifies the size of the original subject of the file. For example, "8.5 in h, 11 in w".

name: text
desc: Dots Per Inch. Stores dots per inch setting of the digitizer used to produce the file, such as "300".

name: text
desc: Engineer. Stores the name of the engineer who worked on the file. If there are multiple engineers, separate the names by a semicolon and a blank. For example, "Smith, John; Adams, Joe".

name: text
desc: SMPTE time code of digitization start point expressed as a NULL terminated text string "HH:MM:SS.FF". If performing MCI capture in AVICAP, this chunk will be automatically set based on the MCI start time.

name: text
desc: Digitization Time. Specifies the time and date that digitization commenced. The digitization time is contained in an ASCII string which contains exactly 26 characters and is in the format "Wed Jan 02 02:03:55 1990\n\0". The ctime(), asctime(), functions can be used to create strings in this format. This chunk is automatically added to the capture file based on the current system time at the moment capture is initiated.

name: code_page
desc: Specifies the code page used for file elements. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if this field has value zero, assume standard ISO 8859/1 code page (identical to code page 1004 without code points defined in hex columns 0, 1, 8, and 9).

name: country_code
desc: Specifies the country code used for file elements. See “ Country Codes,” following this section, for a list of currently defined country codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if this field has value zero, assume USA (country code 001).

name: language
desc: Specify the language and dialect used for file elements. See “Language and Dialect Codes,” later in this chapter, for a list of language and dialect codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if these fields have value zero, assume US English (language code 9, dialect code 1).

name: dialect
desc: Specify the language and dialect used for file elements. See “Language and Dialect Codes,” later in this chapter, for a list of language and dialect codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if these fields have value zero, assume US English (language code 9, dialect code 1).

name: samples
desc: Number of samples. RIFF1991 named this field dwFileSize, even though it's documented as "Number of samples"

name: cue_points
desc: Count of cue points. The number of times the cue-point struct repeats within this chunk.

name: name
desc: cue-point field: Specifies the cue point name. Each <cue-point> record must have a unique dwName field.

name: position
desc: cue-point field: Specifies the sample position of the cue point. This is the sequential sample number within the play order. See [`plst`](@/chunk/plst.md) chunk, for a discussion of the play order.

name: chunk_id
desc: cue-point field: Specifies the name or chunk ID of the chunk containing the cue point.

name: chunk_start
desc: cue-point field: Specifies the file position of the start of the chunk containing the cue point. This is a byte offset relative to the start of the data section of the ‘wavl’ LIST chunk.

name: block_start
desc: cue-point field: Specifies the file position of the start of the block containing the position. This is a byte offset relative to the start of the data section of the ‘wavl’ LIST chunk.

name: sample_offset
desc: cue-point field: Specifies the sample offset of the cue point relative to the start of the block.

name: segments
desc: Count of play segments.

name: name
desc: play-segment field: Specifies the cue point name. This value must match one of the names listed in the [cue](@/chunk/cue.md) cue-point table.

name: length
desc: play-segment field: Specifies the length of the section in samples.

name: loops
desc: play-segment field: Specifies the number of times to play the section.

name: id
desc: The ‘labl’ chunk contains a label, or title, to associate with a cue point.

name: name
desc: Specifies the cue point name. This value must match one of the names listed in the [`cue`](@/chunk/cue.md) chunk' cue-point table.

name: text
desc: Specifies a NULL-terminated string containing a text label.

name: id
desc: The ‘note’ chunk contains comment text for a cue point

name: name
desc: Specifies the cue point name. This value must match one of the names listed in the [`cue`](@/chunk/cue.md) chunk' cue-point table.

name: text
desc: Specifies a NULL-terminated string containing comment text.

name: id
desc: The “ ltxt” chunk contains text that is associated with a data segment of specific length

name: name
desc: Specifies the cue point name. This value must match one of the names listed in the [`cue`](@/chunk/cue.md) chunk' cue-point table.

name: sample_length
desc: Specifies the number of samples in the segment of waveform data.

name: purpose
desc: Specifies the type or purpose of the text. For example, dwPurpose can specify a FOURCC code like 'scrp' for script text or 'capt' for close-caption text.

name: country_code
desc: Specifies the country code for the text. See "Country Codes" in [`CSET`](@/chunk/cset.md) chunk, for a current list of country codes.

name: language
desc: Specify the language for the text. See "Language and Dialect Codes" in [`CSET`](@/chunk/cset.md) chunk, for a current list of language and dialect codes.

name: dialect
desc: Specify the dialect codes for the text. See "Language and Dialect Codes" in [`CSET`](@/chunk/cset.md) chunk, for a current list of language and dialect codes.

name: code_page
desc: Specifies the code page for the text. See [`CSET`](@/chunk/cset.md) chunk for details.

name: id
desc: The 'file' chunk contains information described in other file formats (for example, an 'RDIB' file or an ASCII text file).

name: name
desc: Specifies the cue point name. This value must match one of the names listed in the [`cue`](@/chunk/cue.md) chunk' cue-point table.

name: media_type
desc: Specifies the cue point name. This value must match one of the names listed in the <cue-ck> cue-point table.Specifies the file type contained in the fileData field. If the fileData section contains a RIFF form, the dwMedType field is the same as the RIFF form type for the file. This field can contain a zero value.

name: file_data
desc: Contains the media file.

name: id
desc: MD5 audio data checksum.

name: size
desc: size is always 16 bytes.

name: md5
desc: MD5 checksum of the data chunk, not including the optional badding byte.

name: id
desc: The ‘slnt’ chunk represents silence, not necessarily a repeated zero volume or baseline sample.

name: samples
desc: Number of samples.

name: id
desc: This is the same as WRID>RIFF-WAVE>data, it can also be enclosed in this list type.

name: unshifted_note
desc: MIDI note number that corresponds to the unshifted pitch of the sample. Valid values range from 0 to 127.

name: fine_tune
desc: Pitch shift adjustment in cents (or 100ths of a semitone) needed to hit `unshifted_note` value exactly. `fine_tune` can be used to compensate for tuning errors in the sampling process. Valid values range from -50 to 50.

name: gain
desc: Suggested volume setting for the sample in decibels. A value of zero decibels suggests no change in the volume. A value of -6 decibels suggests reducing the amplitude of the sample by two.

name: low_note
desc: Suggested usable MIDI note number range of the sample. Valid values range from 0 to 127.

name: high_note
desc: Suggested usable MIDI note number range of the sample. Valid values range from 0 to 127.

name: low_velocity
desc: Suggested usable MIDI velocity range of the sample. Valid values range from 0 to 127.

name: high_velocity
desc: Suggested usable MIDI velocity range of the sample. Valid values range from 0 to 127.

name: manufacturer
desc: Specifies the MMA Manufacturer code for the intended target device. The high byte indicates the number of low order bytes (1 or 3) that are valid for the manufacturer code. For example, this value will be 0x01000013 for Digidesign (the MMA Manufacturer code is one byte, 0x13); whereas 0x03000041 identifies Microsoft (the MMA Manufacturer code is three bytes, 0x00 0x00 0x41). If the sample is not intended for a specific manufacturer, then this field should be set to zero.

name: product
desc: Specifies the Product code of the intended target device for the `manufacturer`. If the sample is not intended for a specific manufacturer's product, then this field should be set to zero.

name: sample_period
desc: Specifies the period of one sample in nanoseconds (normally 1/ `samples_per_second` from the WAVEFORMAT structure for the RIFF WAVE file -- however, this field allows fine tuning). For example, 44.1 kHz would be specified as 22675 (0x00005893).

name: midi_unity_note
desc: Specifies the MIDI note which will replay the sample at original pitch. This value ranges from 0 to 127 (a value of 60 represents Middle C as defined by the MMA).

name: midi_pitch_fraction
desc: Specifies the fraction of a semitone up from the specified `midi_unity_note`. A value of 0x80000000 is 1/2 semitone (50 cents); a value of 0x00000000 represents no fine tuning between semitones.

name: smpte_format
desc:
Specifies the SMPTE time format used in the `smpte_offset` field. Possible values are (unrecognized formats should be ignored): 
0 - specifies no SMPTE offset (`smpte_offset` should also be zero). 
24 - specifies 24 frames per second.
25 - specifies 25 frames per second. 
29 - specifies 30 frames per second with frame dropping ('30 drop'). 
30 - specifies 30 frames per second.

name: smpte_offset
desc: Specifies a time offset for the sample if it is to be syncronized or calibrated according to a start time other than 0. The format of this value is 0xhhmmssff. hh is a signed Hours value [-23..23]. mm is an unsigned Minutes value [0..59]. ss is unsigned Seconds value [0..59]. ff is an unsigned value [0..(`smpte_format` - 1)].

name: sample_loop_count
desc: Specifies the number (count) of <`sample-loop`> records that are contained in the <`smpl`> chunk. The <`sample-loop`> records are stored immediately following the `sampler_data` field.

name: sampler_data_size
desc: Specifies the size in bytes of the optional <`sampler_data`>. Sampler specific data is stored imediately following the <`sample-loop`> records. The `sampler_data` field will be zero if no extended sampler specific information is stored in the <`smpl`> chunk.

name: identifier
desc: Identifies the unique 'name' of the loop. This field may correspond with a name stored in the <`cue `> chunk. The name data is stored in the <`LIST-adtl`> chunk.

name: type
desc:
Specifies the loop type:
0 - Loop forward (normal). 
1 - Alternating loop (forward/backward). 
2 - Loop backward. 
3-31 - reserved for future standard types. 
32-? - sampler specific types (manufacturer defined).

name: start
desc: Specifies the startpoint of the loop in samples.

name: end
desc: Specifies the endpoint of the loop in samples (this sample will also be played).

name: fraction
desc: Allows fine-tuning for loop fractional areas between samples. Values range from 0x00000000 to 0xFFFFFFFF. A value of 0x80000000 represents 1/2 of a sample length.

name: play_count
desc: Specifies the number of times to play the loop. A value of 0 specifies an infinite sustain loop.

name: format_tag
desc: A number indicating the WAVE format category of the file. The content of the <format-specific-fields> portion of the ‘fmt’ chunk, and the interpretation of the waveform data, depend on this value.

name: channels
desc: The number of channels represented in the waveform data, such as 1 for mono or 2 for stereo.

name: samples_per_sec
desc: The sampling rate (in samples per second) at which each channel should be played.

name: avg_bytes_per_sec
desc: The average number of bytes per second at which the waveform data should be transferred. Playback software can estimate the buffer size using this value.

name: block_align
desc: The block alignment (in bytes) of the waveform data. Playback software needs to process a multiple of block_align bytes of data at a time, so the value of block_align can be used for buffer alignment. The block_align field should be equal to the following formula, rounded to the next whole number: channels x ( bits_per_sample / 8 )

name: bits_per_sample
desc: The bits_per_sample field specifies the number of bits of data used to represent each sample of each channel. If there are multiple channels, the sample size is the same for each channel. The block_align field should be equal to the following formula, rounded to the next whole number: channels x ( bits_per_sample / 8 )

name: format_tag
desc: A number indicating the WAVE format category of the file. The content of the <format-specific-fields> portion of the ‘fmt’ chunk, and the interpretation of the waveform data, depend on this value.

name: channels
desc: The number of channels represented in the waveform data, such as 1 for mono or 2 for stereo.

name: samples_per_sec
desc: The sampling rate (in samples per second) at which each channel should be played.

name: avg_bytes_per_sec
desc: The average number of bytes per second at which the waveform data should be transferred. Playback software can estimate the buffer size using this value.

name: block_align
desc: The block alignment (in bytes) of the waveform data. Playback software needs to process a multiple of block_align bytes of data at a time, so the value of block_align can be used for buffer alignment. The block_align field should be equal to the following formula, rounded to the next whole number: channels x ( bits_per_sample / 8 )

name: bits_per_sample
desc: The bits_per_sample field specifies the number of bits of data used to represent each sample of each channel. If there are multiple channels, the sample size is the same for each channel. The block_align field should be equal to the following formula, rounded to the next whole number: channels x ( bits_per_sample / 8 )

name: extra_size
desc: The count in bytes of the extra extensible data. The size in bytes of the extra information in the WAVE format header not including the size of the WAVEFORMATEX structure. (size of fields from `format_tag` through `extra_size` inclusive (all fields except `id`, `size` and the `extra_bytes`))

name: extra_bytes
desc: The extra information as bytes. For use when `format_tag` is unknown, so this portion can't be parsed deteriministically.

name: format_tag
desc: A number indicating the WAVE format category of the file. The content of the <format-specific-fields> portion of the ‘fmt’ chunk, and the interpretation of the waveform data, depend on this value. This must be set to WAVE_FORMAT_ADPCM.

name: channels
desc: The number of channels represented in the waveform data, such as 1 for mono or 2 for stereo.

name: samples_per_sec
desc: Frequency of the sample rate of the wave file. This should be 11025, 22050, or 44100. Other sample rates are allowed, but not encouraged.

name: avg_bytes_per_sec
desc: The average number of bytes per second at which the waveform data should be transferred. Playback software can estimate the buffer size using this value. ((samples_per_sec / samples_per_block) * block_align).

name: block_align
desc:
The block alignment (in bytes) of the waveform data. Playback software needs to process a multiple of block_align bytes of data at a time, so the value of block_align can be used for buffer alignment. 

|(samples_per_sec x channels) | block_align |
|-|-|
|8k | 256|
|11k | 256|
|22k | 512|
|44k | 1024|

name: bits_per_sample
desc: This is the number of bits per sample of ADPCM. Currently only 4 bits per sample is defined. Other values are reserved.

name: extra_size
desc: The size in bytes of the extended information after the WAVEFORMATEX structure. For the standard WAVE_FORMAT_ADPCM using the standard seven coefficient pairs, this is 32. If extra coefficients are added, then this value will increase.

name: samples_per_block
desc: Count of number of samples per block. (((block_align - (7 * channels)) * 8) / (bits_per_sample * channels)) + 2.

name: coefficient_count
desc: Count of the number of coefficient sets defined in `coefficients`.

name: coefficients
desc:
These are the coefficients used by the wave to play. They may be interpreted
as fixed point 8.8 signed values. Currently there are 7 preset coefficient sets.
They must appear in the following order.

|Coef1 |Coef2|
|-|-|
|256 |0|
|512 |-256|
|0 |0|
|192 |64|
|240 |0|
|460 |-208|
|392 |-232|

Note that if even only 1 coefficient set was used to encode the file then all
coefficient sets are still included. More coefficients may be added by the
encoding software, but the first 7 must always be the same.

name: format_tag
desc: A number indicating the WAVE format category of the file. The content of the <format-specific-fields> portion of the ‘fmt’ chunk, and the interpretation of the waveform data, depend on this value. This must be set to WAVE_FORMAT_DVI_ADPCM.

name: channels
desc: The number of channels represented in the waveform data, such as 1 for mono or 2 for stereo.

name: samples_per_sec
desc: Sample rate of the WAVE file. This should be 8000, 11025, 22050 or 44100. Other sample rates are allowed.

name: avg_bytes_per_sec
desc: The average number of bytes per second at which the waveform data should be transferred. Playback software can estimate the buffer size using this value. ((samples_per_sec / samples_per_block) * block_align).

name: block_align
desc:
The block alignment (in bytes) of the waveform data. Playback software needs to process a multiple of wBlockAlign bytes of data at a time, so the value of wBlockAlign can be used for buffer alignment. 

|bits_per_sample | block_align |
|-|-|
|3 | (( N * 3 ) + 1 ) * 4 * channels |
|4 | (N + 1) * 4 * channels |
|| where N = 0, 1, 2, 3 . . . |

The recommended block size for coding is 256 * <channels> bytes* min(1, (<samples_per_second>/ 11 kHz))  Smaller values cause the block header to become a more significant storage overhead. But, it is up to the implementation of the coding portion of the algorithm to decide the optimal value for <block_align> within the given constraints (see above). The decoding portion of the algorithm must be able to handle any valid block size. Playback software needs to process a multiple of <block_align> bytes of data at a time, so the value of <block_align> can be used for allocating buffers.

name: bits_per_sample
desc: This is the number of bits per sample of data. DVI ADPCM supports 3 or 4 bits per sample.

name: extra_size
desc: The size in bytes of the extended information after the WAVEFORMATEX structure. This should be 2.

name: samples_per_block
desc:
Count of number of samples per block. 
(((block_align - (4 * channels)) * 8) / (bits_per)sample * channels)) + 1.

name: description
desc:
ASCII string (maximum 256 characters) containing a free description of the sequence. To help applications which display only a short description, it is recommended that a resume of the description is contained in the first 64 characters and the last 192 characters are used for details.

If the length of the string is less than 256 characters the last one shall be followed by a null character (00).

name: originator
desc: ASCII string (maximum 32 characters) containing the name of the originator/ producer of the audio file. If the length of the string is less than 32 characters the field shall be ended by a null character.

name: originator_reference
desc:
ASCII string (maximum 32 characters) containing an unambiguous reference allocated by the originating organisation. If the length of the string is less than 32 characters the field shall be terminated by a null character.

Note: The EBU has defined a format for the OriginatorReference field. See EBU Recommendation R 99 [6].

name: origination_date
desc:
10 ASCII characters containing the date of creation of the audio sequence. The format shall be « ‘,year’,-,’month,’-‘,day,’» with 4 characters for the year and 2 characters per other item.

* Year is defined from 0000 to 9999
* Month is defined from 1 to 12
* Day is defined from 1 to 28, 29, 30 or 31

The separator between the items can be anything but it is recommended that one of the following characters be used:
‘-’ hyphen ‘_’ underscore ‘:’ colon ‘ ’ space ‘.’ stop

name: origination_time
desc:
8 ASCII characters containing the time of creation of the audio sequence. The format shall be « ‘hour’-‘minute’-‘second’» with 2 characters per item.

* Hour is defined from 0 to 23.
* Minute and second are defined from 0 to 59.

The separator between the items can be anything but it is recommended that one of the following characters be used:
‘-’ hyphen ‘_’ underscore ‘:’ colon ‘ ’ space ‘.’ stop

name: time_reference
desc:
These fields shall contain the time-code of the sequence. It is a 64-bit value which contains the first sample count since midnight. The number of samples per second depends on the sample frequency which is defined in the field nSamplesPerSec from the `fmt ` chunk. 

(WAVRef note: This is actually specified as two separate u32 integers, low, then high. On modern 64bit machines, it seems less error prone to just parse it as a single value.)

name: version
desc:
An unsigned binary number giving the version of the BWF. This number is
particularly relevant for the carriage of the UMID and loudness
information. For Version 1 it shall be set to 0x0001 and for Version 2 it
shall be set to 0x0002.

name: umid
desc: 64 bytes containing a UMID (Unique Material Identifier) to standard SMPTE 330M [1]. If only a 32 byte "basic UMID" is used, the last 32 bytes should be set to zero. (The length of the UMID is given internally.)

name: loudness_value
desc: A 16-bit signed integer, equal to round(100x the Integrated Loudness Value of the file in LUFS).

name: loudness_range
desc: A 16-bit signed integer, equal to round(100x the Loudness Range of the file in LU).

name: max_true_peak_level
desc: A 16-bit signed integer, equal to round(100x the Maximum True Peak Value of the file in dBTP).

name: max_momentary_loudness
desc: A 16-bit signed integer, equal to round(100x the highest value of the Momentary Loudness Level of the file in LUFS).

name: max_short_term_loudness
desc:
A 16-bit signed integer, equal to round(100x the highest value of the Short-term Loudness Level of the file in LUFS).

Note: The loudness terms are explained in EBU Recommendation R 128 [2], EBU Tech 3341 [7] and EBU Tech 3342 [8], supported by EBU Tech 3343 and EBU Tech 3344

name: reserved
desc: 180 bytes reserved for extension. If the Version field is set to 0x0001 or 0x0002, these 180 bytes shall be set to a NULL (zero) value.

name: coding_history
desc:
Unrestricted ASCII characters containing a collection of strings terminated by CR/LF. Each string shall contain a description of a coding process applied to the audio data. Each new coding application shall add a new string with the appropriate information.

This information shall contain the type of sound (PCM or MPEG) with its specific parameters :

PCM : mode (mono, stereo), size of the sample (8, 16 bits) and sample frequency, 

MPEG : sample frequency, bit rate, layer (I or II) and the mode (mono, stereo, joint stereo or dual channel), 

It is recommended that the manufacturers of the coders provide an ASCII string for use in the coding history.

Note: The EBU has defined a format for coding history which will simplify the interpretation of the information provided in this field. See EBU Recommendation R 98 [9].
